Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2008 05:24AM Jay wrote: MRi has its advantages as well to the spine..But if the bone scan and PET/CT are both negative you have your answer.  The best evaluation is to have a PET before you recieve any Chemotherapy.  This can than be done at any time in the future after or during Chemotherapy to establish response and and progression of disease.  I stress to always get a PET and if it is negative than get a bone scan.  If it is posative a bone scane will give no further information than what the PET already gave you.  It is a more accurate test. Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2008 08:28AM Jay wrote: I have been scanning cancer patinets for 4 years now with PET/CT. I will tell everyone fromallof the lectures and literature that for Breast cancer this should always been done as a staging scan.  The overall accuracy in PET/CT vs bone scan and CT combined is better.  It also is 15% more accurate than the 2 combined in detectionof early reccurance of disease.  As far as after chemo, PEt/CT will miss come osteoblastic lesions.  This is why they work in tandem together.  If your Oncologist does not order at Pet/CT  than have them look up some data on it.  This is a new test so now all Oncologists are used to it andnot all insurances cover it.  But believe me from someone who has scanned over a thousand woman with breast cancer this is the best test for you.  This is also they best way to evaluate if chemo. is working and a PEt/CT scan done duringa cycle of chemo will help evaluate response to treatment..please do more research and get a PET scan today..I tell eveyone I know and love to do this J

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2008 08:36AM Jay wrote: "Anyway, after the PET scan showed "hot spots", he had me do the bone scan to confirm the mets." PET is more sensative and Specific than Bone scan..in this case it is not necassary. "But the bone scan won't show organ mets...or will it????" No bone only PET will help in liver, lung, breast and bone. "am very new to this topic of bone mets......and will be honest in that I don't really understand what this is but it is scaring me.  I had a bilateral mastectomy in May of 2006.  Last week I found a lump under my left armpit which I am getting checked out next week.  For the last year or so I have been experiencing alot of back pain which I have been assuming is osteo arthritis - I am 48 yrs young.  Sometimes the pain is in more than just my lower back - upper back, hips, shoulders and neck.  I have felt under the weather like I'm coming down with something, but never really get anything, for the last 3 to 4 months. I wonder if I should ask my doctor next week about getting a bone scan? Thoughts?" Please geta PET as well..PET is more accurate in detecting reccurance of breast cancer than CT, Bone scan, and US all 3 combined..I can share the article if you are interested "So for all with bone mets, it seems Bone Scan is the way to go." Combination is the current recomendation Bone scan is 70% sensative for lytic bone lesions PET is 98% sensative. Pet is 75% sensative for blastic lesions, Bone scan is 99%. They need to have an overlap..they each will miss lesions. Most new breast cancer with bone mets are lytic lesions..so PET should be the first scan ordered.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2008 11:40AM Jay wrote: Im glad I could give some help. As far as CT goes, it normally is very poor for detecting bone lesions.  It will miss far more than PET or bone scan.  What becomes the challange for an oncologist is once you receive chemo.  any lytic lesion will be treated and than change into a blastic or sclerotic lesion.  The basis on blastic lesion is bone breakdown and rebuilding.  This is why a PET before chemo is the most helpful.  Any restaging than will show if the patient is responded to any treatment.  The problem is most Oncologists are old school, and might have been doing things the same way for the last 15 years.  I have patients that are more educated than the oncologists.  They have lots to learn becasue PET/CT is such a new advanced test.  Let me know if you have any more questions.  One thing is for sure if your Oncologist says a CT and bone scan is better than a PET/CT..I suggest you have them show you some articles or proof of this..otherwise they need to order the best test for you J
